--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "lars_v_hansen" <lvh@d...> wrote:
> Hi everybody
> 
> 
> We started experimenting with NEAT but we have a few questions that
> some of you might be able to answer.
> 
> 1) The error that you can set on an organism - what range should 
the
> error be in? Our fitness is measured by the Bankroll of each player
> after 600 hands in Texas Hold'em (Limit).
> 
> The players begin with 10.000$. We don't want to punish players 
that
> haven't lost money, but those that have should be assigned some 
sort
> of error. Our own idea is to make it 10.000$ - Bankroll. Is that 
an OK
> error measure?
> 

I think it depends on the other components of fitness.  Is the lost 
money the only fitness measure?  If so, it's most useful to make 
sure that the fitness of ones that lose the worst are significantly 
less than those that lose the least.  Sometimes squaring or 
something like that can help emphasize the disparity.  Keep in mind 
that the size of a species is proportional to it's average fitness.  
Therefore, if fitnesses do not cover a good relative range, the 
species will all end up about the same size.  

> 2) What effect does the "champion" setting (set to true) have on an
> organism during epoch ?
> 

The champion is duplicated into the next for any species above (I 
think) size 4.  It is a form of elitism.  It helps a lot, in general.

> 3)Some times the NEAT engine writes "performing delta coding". Is 
this
> a bad thing?
> 
> 

It's not bad necessarily; it just means that your best species has 
not improved in the last dropoff_age+5 generations, where 
dropoff_age is defined in the parameters (.ne) file.

I suggest making dropoff_age really high, like 500, for your initial 
experiments.  That way it won't ever delta code.  And that's fine 
for a really long run, since it isn't really necessary after only a 
few generations of stagnation.

What delta-coding does is focus in on only the top 2 species and 
kill the rest off.  It's a focusing measure when things aren't 
working out.  But I suspect you setting is doing it way too soon.
You don't usually need it as much as you might think if you are 
willing to go for hundreds of generations.

> Our initial test results currently shows that the best individual 
have
> picked up that it is important for them to play aggressively when 
they
> have one hole card that is a part of the current best hand. This is
> not at all a good player but it doesn't take the players more than
> about 10 generations to pick up on this feature. Our hope is that
> after a couple of hundred generations we will have a players that 
is a
> little bit stronger.
> 

Certainly you should play at least a few hundred generations to get 
an idea if your experiment is working or not.

> The players are playing against a fixed opponent that always call.
> This way they should be forced only to play the good hands.
> 
> Out goal is to continue training but switch the opponent once the
> players show signs that they can play convincingly better than this
> opponent.
> 

Good luck, please continue to post on your progress.

ken
